page.title: 18ENGLEFIELD HOUSE
page.content: Englefield House is the largest building in the sector. It has a late Elizabethan E-plan and its three storied facade has flint patternings. Parts of the long gallery date to the 1550's, but much of the house and park which can still be seen were built in about 1600. Further building work took place from the 1770's. The east front has a Victorian ashlar-faced tower and a porch which is large enough to allow a coach and horse to enter. In the 1820's tall, square turrets, many of them disguising chimney stacks, were built. The front gates were built in 1862 to commemorate the marriage of the owner, Richard Fellowes Benyon, to Elizabeth Clutterbuck and there have been no radical additions or alterations since. At present the building is in an excellent state of repair.
